ImageData.LabelName: Cancer in lymph nodes around trachea
Primary tumor is 5 cm or smaller
Part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Added color to two ribs on the lower right side of the figure
Made figure male, updated skin tone to FP V
Changed the wording in the top right inset to say “Primary tumor is 5 cm or smaller”; and added a label for Pleura on the bottom left side of the figure.
No additional changes made to image

Changed the title to Stage IIIA Lung Cancer (1); made the label “Cancer in lymph nodes around trachea” the same size as the other labels; changed the letter “c” in the main figure to an “a” and moved it up; changed the letter “ c” in the lower inset to a “b”; moved the cancer spot and small box that has the lines to the lower inset up in the main figure so that the cancer spot in the small box is up closer to the main primary cancer spot; changed the letter “e” in the main figure to a “c”; and changed the label “Part or all of the lung has collapsed” to “Part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis” and removed the “e.” in front of the label.
Revisions made to image per AJCC 8th edition staging

Diagnoses.Diagnosis: stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Stage IIIA lung cancer (1); drawing shows a primary tumor (5 cm or smaller) in the left lung (top inset) and cancer in lymph nodes around the trachea. Also shown is cancer that has spread to (a) the left main bronchus and (b) the membrane covering the lung (bottom inset). Also shown is (c) part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation). The carina, pleura, and a rib (bottom inset) are also shown.

Stage IIIA lung cancer (1); drawing shows a primary tumor (5 cm or smaller) in the left lung (top inset) and cancer in lymph nodes around the trachea. Also shown is cancer that has spread to (a) the left main bronchus and (b) the membrane covering the lung (bottom inset). Also shown is (c) part or all of the lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation). The carina, pleura, and a rib (bottom inset) are also shown.

Captions.MediaCaption: Stage IIIA lung cancer (1). The tumor is 5 centimeters or smaller and cancer has spread to lymph nodes on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor. The lymph nodes with cancer are around the trachea or aorta (not shown), or where the trachea divides into the bronchi. Also, one or more of the following may be found: (a) cancer has spread to the main bronchus, but has not spread to the carina; and/or (b) cancer has spread to the inner membrane that covers the lung; and/or (c) part of the lung or the whole lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation of the lung).

Stage IIIA lung cancer (1). The tumor is 5 centimeters or smaller and cancer has spread to lymph nodes on the same side of the chest as the primary tumor. The lymph nodes with cancer are around the trachea or aorta (not shown), or where the trachea divides into the bronchi. Also, one or more of the following may be found: (a) cancer has spread to the main bronchus, but has not spread to the carina; and/or (b) cancer has spread to the inner membrane that covers the lung; and/or (c) part of the lung or the whole lung has collapsed or has pneumonitis (inflammation of the lung).
